title: Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) Analyzer
description: Interprets arterial blood gas results to determine acid-base status, respiratory compensation, and metabolic derangements

parameters.name: pco2
parameters.description: Partial pressure of carbon dioxide in arterial blood

parameters.name: po2
parameters.description: Partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood (optional for oxygenation assessment)

parameters.name: fio2
parameters.description: Fraction of inspired oxygen (optional, expressed as decimal: 0.21 for room air)

result.name: abg_interpretation
result.description: Complete arterial blood gas interpretation including acid-base status and compensation

ranges.interpretation: Low pH with low bicarbonate indicates metabolic acidosis. Assess for respiratory compensation and calculate anion gap.
Low pH with high CO2 indicates respiratory acidosis. Assess for metabolic compensation.
High pH with high bicarbonate indicates metabolic alkalosis. Assess for respiratory compensation.
High pH with low CO2 indicates respiratory alkalosis. Assess for metabolic compensation.
pH is normal. Assess for mixed disorders or compensated acid-base disturbances.

references: Seifter JL. Acid-base disorders. In: Jameson J, Fauci AS, Kasper DL, Hauser SL, Longo DL, Loscalzo J. eds. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20e. McGraw Hill; 2018.
Kraut JA, Madias NE. Serum anion gap: its uses and limitations in clinical medicine. Clin J Am Soc Nephrol. 2007;2(1):162-74.
Berend K, de Vries AP, Gans RO. Physiological approach to assessment of acid-base disturbances. N Engl J Med. 2014;371(15):1434-45.
MDCalc. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) Analyzer. Available at: https://www.mdcalc.com/calc/1741/arterial-blood-gas-abg-analyzer
formula: Primary disorder determined by pH direction and primary parameter (HCO3 for metabolic, PCO2 for respiratory). Compensation assessed using Winter's formula for metabolic acidosis: Expected PCO2 = 1.5 × [HCO3] + 8 (±2)
notes: Normal values: pH 7.35-7.45, PCO2 35-45 mmHg, HCO3 22-26 mEq/L
For metabolic acidosis, calculate anion gap: Na - (Cl + HCO3). Normal: 8-12 mEq/L
Winter's formula applies only to pure metabolic acidosis
Always consider clinical context and additional laboratory values
Mixed disorders may be present, especially in critically ill patients
